This is the home stretch. September WTI crude oil futures attempted a breakout on Wednesday, touching $43.52, as EIA stocks fell by 7.4 million barrels in the week ended July 31. They later fell back to virtually unchanged on the week at $41.60.  Option market implied probabilities are <$25: 0%, $25-$35: 0%, $35-$45: 94%, $45-55: 6%, >$55: 0% As China is likely to retaliate next week for the US Health Secretary visit to Taiwan and the Tik Tok/WeChat ban, and EIA stats are unlikely to materially improve on last Wednesday's bullish picture, I now see virtually no chance of >$45 or <$35 for the short time remaining.

At this late stage of my forecast a plummet in demand or massive increase in production is not feasible to drive price less than < $25.00
25.00-35.00 has some potential due to national interest decisions that could be made to announce intent to not comply with OPEC+ agreement by affected parties. Again, due to late stage of forecast this is not likely swing as Iraq just announced intent to comply with OPEC+ and Saudi Arabia and Russia just reaffirmed their partnership.  
35.00-45.00 is most likely due to short time left for this forecast to end and the current price. No major meetings are planned it appears.  There does seem to be some increase in usage, however last day or so indicates inventory may also be rising.  
45.00-55.00 is possible due to desired upward pressure wanted by OPEC+ deal which could manifest into the $4 increase needed in the last 5 days of this forecasting window. 
>55.00 unknowns such as potential health complications to King Salman which could create a discontinuity in Saudi political order if he passes.  additionally, a world event such as an attack on oil industry in a major oil producing country - Saudi Arabia, Iraq - or a potential mil-mil interaction in South China sea between US and China making US China relations worsen. If one of these significant events occurs - traders could tighten market and drive up demand

Oil currently stands at $40.83/barrel. After a tumultuous first half to the year, with both demand and supply side shocks that created incredibly high levels of market volatility, in the past month the oil price has steadied. Part of the volatility this spring was created by unexpected lower demand as lockdowns were rolled out around the globe. Air travel was at 4% of usual levels in the US. That represents an unprecedented low for an industry that uses a large amount of oil based fuel. Most importantly, the reduction in oil demand was so rapid that there was a major glut of oil in the market. At one point, there was so much oil in Cushing, OK that the front month oil futures went negative. Furthermore, Russia and OPEC were struggling to negotiation any sort of supply reduction. This also sent the price down precipitously earlier in the year. There is no expected OPEC news in the coming three weeks, which simplifies this question.  As the US recovers, the price of WTI has ticked up slowly and steadied. The price of oil will likely fall if shutdowns and lockdowns return to the US. With several weeks of extremely high infection totals, it seems likely that the market has priced in the mass infection we are currently experience, and will continue to experience for, at minimum, several weeks. If lockdowns return before Aug 14th, I will have to update my prediction accordingly. Oil companies have projected oil prices in the high 40’s to mid 50’s by 2021, with a gradual linear increase until then. Of course, these projections must be taken with a grain of salt as higher oil prices benefit petroleum firms. "Shell now expects a barrel to cost $40 in 2021 and $50 in 2022, down from the $60 it assumed in its most recent annual report. BP forecasts that Brent will average $55 from 2021 until 2050. Just a few months ago its central assumption for prices over the next 20 years was $70.” (Economist) We can approximate the distribution of oil prices by using oil options traded on the NYMEX. The $40 straddle on the Aug future is trading at ~$4. From these options, implied volatility in oil futures is 37.12% annually. There are 15 trading days before the 13th of August. Implied volatility for this time period could be calculated as  Vol = 37.12% / sqrt(252/15)
=9.1% So we can expect that the distribution of oil prices is going to be normal with a mean of $40.83 and a std of 9.1% or 3.7. With this insight, a final prediction can be made. 
<25 = 0%
25-35 = 6%
35-45 = 81%
45-55 = 13%
>55 = 0%

Lots of people are over-indexing on a paltry US economic recovery as the major causal factor in the price of oil. In actuality, the US only consumes ~20% of the world's oil. Granted, WTI is drilled in the US, but if prices are higher elsewhere, it will be exported. The rest of the world is recovering far better than the US is, thanks to its superior virus response. Therefore, outside of some kind of black swan event over the next few weeks, I don't expect oil to decline below $35.

Some isolated considerations: • WTI has only once in the last twenty years dipped below $25. That was on April 24 of this year, at the height of the pandemic.
• On a quarterly basis, WTI tends to stay within the same ten-dollar band.
• The recent leap from the April low, $20 higher to $40, is the largest leap ever. So some takeaways are that values below 25 and values above 55 are both pretty unlikely. Another thing to think about is that the 45-55 band is only slightly more likely than >55; that would constitute something like a full recovery to pre-crisis prices, which still seems a little unlikely to me. The internet says that the three factors affecting oil prices are current demand, current supply, and future supply. The CNBC article says that production will be kept low through July, and it seems likely that demand will not change appreciably (though some states are reopening, others are considering locking down again). That means artificially high prices. Both Russia and Saudi depend on stable, high, oil prices, which are increasingly important particularly for Saudi, now that Hajj will be severely restricted. It seems likely the agreement to keep production low will be extended.

Furthermore, stimulus packages are reducing the economic impact of the current recession. If stimulus lessens and jobs continue disappearing, demand will follow suit. This concept can be seen in WTI price drops like the last recession (3). Crude volatility/random walk-like model [1] with some subjective factors that I adjusted to somewhat match the crowd. I decided to use the target price as the latest futures quote for Aug 2020 [2], despite there being mixed evidence [3] for futures being much better than random walk: "Alquist, Kilian and Vigfusson (2011) find that oil futures prices are generally no better at predicting spot prices than a random walk. At a twelve-month horizon they may marginally outperform a random walk, but this result is sensitive to the sample period and data frequency chosen. On the other hand, Chernenko, Schwarz and Wright (2004) conclude that the oil futures price predicts spot prices correctly on average; Wu and McCallum (2005) agree, but observe that the forecasting errors are large. Reichsfeld and Roache (2011) find that the oil futures price outperforms a random walk at the three-month horizon but is no better at longer horizons. Overall, then, the results from the literature are mixed. But they do not strongly suggest that the futures curve is a much better predictor of spot prices than a random walk." This model [4] seems promising, but it's way over my head. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=2064373776
[2] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/light-sweet-crude.html
[3] https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/quarterly-bulletin/2012/what-can-the-oil-futures-curve-tell-us-about-the-outlook-for-oil-prices.pdf
[4] https://www.researchgate.net/publication/255724775_Small_Trends_and_Big_Cycles_in_Crude_Oil_Prices

A tough question to forecast since it takes us almost as far further forward into the Covid crisis as we’ve currently run (end Jan to mid May, mid May to mid August) and so many huge and wild things have happened already... So, with due deference and timidity, a simple model: - WTI price a function of a) economic activity in world economy and b) restrictions on supply, either via deliberate supplier restriction (eg OPEC), or external disruptions to supply (another from conflict to eg banks withdrawing credit for their own reasons or because projects aren’t viable at ‘new normal’ prices - on the first part of the ‘equation’, three scenarios a) a bit better cos unlocking restores economic activity but there’s still a lot of damage and disruption already done to account for, b) quite a lot worse, unlocking doesn’t do much and second order effects (international economy, supply chain disruption etc) continue to compound or c) some mixture of the two that balances out to an bit worse’ - on the second, OPEC plus seem to be trying to restrict supply with initial moves reported for several countries. Scenarios a) it works a bit but is minor relative to the demand shock or b) it doesn’t work at all (they couldn’t make it work in better times and need for state and firm revenue now more acute so incentives to defect high. The disruption of supply element feels significant tho, with projects that aren’t long term viable at these prices being squeezed out over time (there’s a dependency on the economic expectations above that I’m not going to try and model, but it has equilibriating properties cos worse economy makes projects less viable more quickly, I think. So overall, to August, I think a modest up arrow in prices? - to note, I know there are specific WTI issues about US storage capacity etc that I’m not expert enough to capture - so there’s a known gap there. Taking all of the above and applying it qualitatively to the current price of $29 gives me the spread above.

I think a lot of people are using futures prices to predict this, which is incorrect due to storage costs. The way a commodities futures price is calculated: Spot * (risk-free-rate - convenience yield + storage costs).  The storage costs variable is massively pushing up the price of oil futures contracts, and likely doesn't reflect what the actual spot price will be on the settlement date.

From 2010 to 2014, the median Cushing price was ~$112 PPB.  OPEC tried to bust USA shale producers in 2014.  Didn’t work.  Once the world oil producers recognized that USA shale could be profit-making at ~$55 PPB, the median Cushing PPB stayed there for 5 years.  Until recently, oil demand had been on the rise since 2008, but not anymore.  We’re in for another stepwise reduction.   The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) Short-Term Energy Outlook released April 7th projected a 12% reduction in world consumption in 2020Q2.  Credible reports of more than 50% reduction in miles driven and more than 90% reduction in miles flown suggests that we will see a much greater reduction in 2020Q2.   EIA also assumes a V-shaped recovery with oil production and consumption in-balance in the middle of the 3rd quarter.  In the United States at least, application of the White House's Opening Up America Again guidelines gets the Country into Phase 3 in the middle of the summer at the earliest with sometime in the fall being more likely.  It could be later if local re-openings go poorly and hot spots develop.  Even Phase 3 retains some restrictions that will hinder commerce.  The recovery is more likely to be prolonged with an asymptotic leveling out. Oil stocks are largely full with oil mostly acquired at ~$55 PPB.  The lowest cost oil producers worldwide can make money substantially below that value.  If worldwide consumption comes down by 50%, the lowest costs producers can fill demand and make money above ~$23 PPB.  This rises to ~$32 PPB at 25% reduction in consumption.  We may only asymptotically approach $55 PPB again.

There are multiple factors at play, but the main issue impacting price at the moment is demand side as opposed to supply side. Factors include:
Saudi budgeted oil price for 2020 $55/b
Saudi break even point $85/b anything less than $30/b results in a budget deficit
Oil makes up 85% of Saudi revenue and 42% of GDP
Russian break even point $42.50/b
Oil and gas makes up 46% of Russian gov expenditure and 30% of GDP
US break even point $46/b Investment ties and relationships:
$3 Billion arms deal and investment contracts between Russia and Saudi.
Further $10 billion in Saudi direct investment in Russia. Responsibilities:
Aramco is now a listed company and is responsible for share holder interests.
Pressure from other oil producing Gulf States.
Saudi bond market hit, potential liquidity issues as lenders feel pressure from Covid 19 impact.
70% increase in debt default insurance for Saudi. On top of all of this, there is a massive glut of oil on the market already as a result of the Covid 19 global shut down. Estimates range from 3.5mb/d to 10mb/d surplus in Q2 2020. Even if agreement was reached tomorrow, the excess supply will outpace demand into Q3. Possibly some improvement in price in Q3.

Why the Oil Price Crash of 2020 will be short January 2020 brought troubles to the oilfield, a coronavirus known as CoVid-19. Originating in China, it spread faster than flu, and more deadly. To combat it, Chinese authority imposed quarantines, and other social distancing measures. It worked, but the engines of industry ground down and the Chinese economy needed less and less oil. This led to a surplus of 2+ million barrels per day. Fast forward to March, a worldwide pandemic is underway and economies are slowing down rapidly. IHS Markit believes CoVid-19 will cause 3.8 million barrels spare capacity to hit the markets. OPEC + has suffered a possible fatal blow, Russia no longer wants to go along with cuts recommend by OPEC led by Saudi Arabia. So the Saudis have ramped up production to 12 million to flood the market and teach Russia a lesson about unity. That now puts 5.8 million surplus barrels into the worlds supply. That is why oil has fallen from $50s down to $27 before it stabilized at $33 at the time of this writing. In a nutshell, this is a show of spite in game theory. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spite_(game_theory)
Saudi and Russia did not agree upon some master strategy to destroy American shale production to regain market share, cripple the global economy for world domination, or part of some scheme by the Illuminati to take control of the UN. Rather it is just a punitive action against a reticent partner. It occurred after a failed negotiation that gives us a clue to the duration. Saudi has cash reserves to go 3 years at $33/bbl and make their budget, Russia for even longer. Sure, one could argue they could drain their reserves to teach the other a lesson, but that is not rational behavior by heads of state. Russia just wanted a better deal, the Saudis wanted fairness. They will likely hammer out a palatable comprise within weeks. Rumors have it that negotiations are still happening. On the other hand, China has shown signs that it’s epidemic has burned out. We expected a normal epidemic curve of 2-3 months up, and 2-3 months down, but if we are to trust Chinese numbers, they suppressed the epidemic curve to just 3 months. There is now an immediate push to jump up the economy, within weeks or months they should be consuming more oil, hopefully taking 1-2 million barrels off the market. That is good news, and better, inevitable. Almost nothing can stop the post-epidemic recovery, for any country. I took a survey of oilfield executives and asked the simple question of “How many months will oil stay below $40/bbl?” Answers: 2,2,3,5,6,6,9,9,12 Mean: 6 StDev:3.4 68% range: 2.5 to 9.5 months. If a Saudi-Russian reduction agreement happens, oil should at least get to the mid 40s range. Then if China gets back on line, they should drive up oil ~$5/bbl more. It may be up to a year before we hit mid $50 oil, but upper $40s should happen within 3-6 months.
There will be a rebound in demand after China recovers from corona. US will intercede in the Saudi-Russia price war as many US smaller and high-debt companies will feel the price squeeze.

4 reasons: 1) OPEC+ producers can clearly see that the oil demand is going to collapse with the emergence of renewable energy, particularly electric vehicles, so they they don’t want to hold a stranded assets so they’ll sell at any price.  2) Russia and Saudi are obviously cooperating to crush the US shale industry which has a much higher minimum cost of production and a high level of private debt - so once the shale producers fail to generate enough cash flow to service their debts, these producers go under. When Secretary Pompeo was in Eastern Europe earlier in the year and offered to sell them as much oil and gas at a market rate, this probably sparked Russian unease and drove the Russians to seek to push the US out of the fossil fuel energy production. 3) US oil producers have their entire 2020 production hedged out through the year end into the start of 2021. Therefore, any desire to put pressure on these producers by the Saudis and the Russians and OPEC+ means that they have to keep the price low or drive it lower throughout the year. Hence, my confidence in a very low oil forecast. This forecast is also very low because when markets collapse like this they can stay quite low for longer periods than most people expect and they tend to build a base before prices go up again. 4) There exists the outside possibility but worth noting because of its strategic importance that US oil producers are cooperating with the Russians and the Saudis based on their mutual desire to push oil prices so low that it upends the world movement to renewable energy and puts the electric car industry out of business. It could simply be their overarching objective through the year 2021 that they all will lower oil prices to the floor and keep their consumers using oil in all things and forget about carbon taxes, renewable energy, and non-internal combustion engine powered vehicles.
